Award.AwardTitle: What are the Mechanisms of Feeding and Feedback in Nearby AGN?
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to conduct disk-wind simulations that extend previous work from 2-D to 3-D and simultaneously account for radiation, thermal and magnetic driving effects. The program will address the following questions: 1) How are AGN (Active Galactic Nuclei) fed on scales of tens to hundreds of parsecs, and what is the relationship between feeding and feedback? 2) How frequent are mass outflows in the NLRs of AGN as a function of intrinsic AGN properties like black-hole mass, luminosity, and Eddington ratio, and what are their mass outflow rates and kinetic luminosities? 3) What is the connection between nuclear star formation and AGN activity?

Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate and graduate students and a postdoc, a website to distribute data, and a multimedia presentation to attract high school students into science majors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supermassive black holes (SMBHs), with masses of a million to a billion times that of the Sun, are now known to exist in the centers of most, if not all, galaxies. They may play a key role in the formation and evolution of galaxies and large-scale structure in the Universe, and yet the details of how they interact with their environments are poorly known. We have initiated a research program to understand how SMBHS are fed as they acumulate gas and dust from their host galaxies to form accretion disks, which radiate tremendous amounts of energy. We are also interested in studying how the radiation from these active galactic nuclei (AGN) in turn pushes gas back out of the central regions. In particular, we are interested in determining if this "AGN feedback" is powerful enough to drive material out of the centers of galaxies to terminate star formation and control the growth and evolution of their central bulges.

Our procedure has been to resolve the motions of both molecular and ionized gas in nearby AGN to determine the geometry and physical mechanisms of feeding and feedback. We have used new observations with the Gemini 8-meter telescope in Hawaii and the Near Infrared Field Spectrometer (NIFS), which allows us to approach the angular resolution obtained with the Hubble Space Telescope (HST). This novel instrumentation allows us to obtain spectra at many adjascent points around the AGN, and thereby obtain maps of the gas motions with a single observation in each band. We supplement these observations with previous spectra from HST and with new spectra obtained of the entire galaxies with ground-based spectra from the Apache Point 3.5-meter telescope in New Mexico, in order to understand how the large-scale motions connect to those at small scales.

From our studies, we have established a connection between AGN feeding and feedback. Gas that is initially rotating in the galaxy is funneled into the central regions (about 1000 light years across), until it enters the bright cones of radiation from the AGN. Much of this gas is ionized and driven back into the galaxy by radiation pressure from the AGN. For one of these AGN, we have used HST images and spectra to determine that the mass outflows are powerful enough to provide significant feedback to their environments, and we are expanding these studies to other AGN to test their overall significance. We have also discovered a case of a bright AGN that is being fueled by a dwarf galaxy that ventured too close to the center of the AGN host galaxy and was ripped apart. Our current and future work concentrates on the overall significance of feeding and feedback by studying their properties as a function of host galaxy and SMBH properties, as well at their connection to star formation or termination.

This research project has provided training for several future scientists: a postdoctoral research associate, two graduate students, and an undergraduate research assistant. It has been used to spur public interest in science, astronomy, and black holes, as well as excite and motivate high school and undergraduate students, through public talks and other presentations. A web site is being generated to distribute the processed data to the astronomical community and to include public outreach pages on black holes and AGN. The site will be made available after the major results from this research are published in scientific journals.
